subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: All right, let's do a deep dive into this paper about late chunking for contextual embeddings.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Sounds good.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Now, AI idols, they need to break large texts down into smaller chunks, Right. To be able to process them.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Yeah.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Think about how AI assistants can summarize, like, whole articles for you.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Right, Exactly.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: But splitting text can sometimes create problems with the context and meaning. Yeah. And that can mean less effective embeddings.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Yeah.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: That's where this late chunking comes in. It aims to solve this in a really clever way.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: It does. It's a very interesting paper, for sure, highlighting this challenge we have in AI and natural language processing specifically, which is how do you maintain that context while still working with these manageable chunks of data?

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Okay, so paint a picture for our listener. How does this problem play out in a real world example?

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Sure. So imagine you have a long Wikipedia article all about Berlin, full of history and cultural. Cultural insights. Maybe even some fun facts about the city.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Yeah.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Now, if you were to just chop this article up into sentence sized chunks.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Okay.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: The later chunks might have pronouns like it or the city.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Right.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Without actually mentioning Berlin.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: So for us humans, it's obvious that it refers to Berlin.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Exactly.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Because we have the context.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Right.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: But for the AI, just looking at that one sentence.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Just looking at that one sentence. Yeah. They have no idea what it refers to. It's like you're trying to, you know, watch a movie and you just watch one line of the movie.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Yeah.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: You're missing a lot of information.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Right. And the paper actually illustrates this problem with a visual from a Wikipedia article.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Yes, that's figure one in the paper. And it really helps to visualize this.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Right.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: You can see how, you know, chopping up the text leads to these little isolated pieces of information that have no context.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Okay, so context is key.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Yeah.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: But we still need to work with manageable chunks of data.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Right.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: So how does this late chunking method actually solve this problem?

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Well, it takes advantage of these long context embedding models. And these models are designed to handle much larger pieces of text. So instead of chunking the text before, you feed it to the model.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Right.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Late chunking does it afterwards.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: So you're saying we feed the whole text to the model first?

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: That's right.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: We let it process the full context and then we split the resulting token embeddings into chunks.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Exactly.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: That seems counterintuitive.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Yeah, it seems counterintuitive, but it's actually really smart because you're letting the model see the big picture first. You know, understand all the Relationships. And then you break it down.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: So each chunk embedding now carries that contextual information from the entire text.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Exactly.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Not just from that one little chunk.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Yeah, it's like if you were doing a jigsaw puzzle.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Okay.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: And you got to see the picture on the box before you started putting the pieces together.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Yeah, that's a great analogy.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: It makes a lot more sense. Right, right, it does. And actually figure two in the paper compares the naive chunking, where you split first and then embed to the late chunking approach. And you can visually see the difference there.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Okay. So they've got this clever new method. It seems to make a lot of sense.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Yeah.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: But did they actually test it?

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Oh, yeah.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Did it work?

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: They did, yeah. They used a benchmark called bir, which is specifically designed to evaluate retrieval tasks.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Okay.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: So you can think of it kind of like testing how good a search engine is at finding the right document from, like, a ton of documents.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Okay. So it's a head to head to see which approach is better.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Right.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: So what were the results?

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Well, the results were pretty good.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Okay.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Late chunking was better than the traditional approach across all the data sets.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: So it wasn't just like a small improvement?

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: No, it was a pretty significant improvement.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: That's exciting.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Yeah. And it gets even more interesting when you look at longer documents.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Okay. Why?

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: It seems like the benefit of late chunking gets even bigger.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Okay.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: When you have more context to work with.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Why do you think that is?

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Well, I think it makes sense because longer documents tend to have more complicated relationships between ideas, more pronouns and references.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: That really depend on the broader context.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Yeah.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: So this ability to capture that full context with late chunking.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Right.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Seems to give it a real advantage.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: This could be a big deal for how we use AI to handle large texts.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Oh, yeah. Think about it.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Right.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Legal documents, research papers, all of these things rely on context to be able to understand them properly.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Okay, so give me a real world example of how late chunking could impact something like a search engine.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Okay, so let's say you're searching on Google for best restaurants in Berlin with outdoor seating. Andy. Vegan options.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Okay. Very specific.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Very specific. Right. A traditional search engine might just find restaurants with outdoor seating or vegan options. Right. But it wouldn't understand that all three of those things are important to you. Yeah, but with late chunking, okay. The search engine could understand all three of those desires are linked.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: So it's not just about keywords anymore.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: It's about understanding the nuance and the intent.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: That's right.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: What about other areas like chatbots or AI assistant?

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: The potential is huge there.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Okay.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Because you could have a chatbot that understands all the nuances of a long conversation, remembers key details, and responds in a way that makes sense, you know, given the overall context of the conversation.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Yeah. It's like having an AI that can actually have a conversation with you.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: That's right. And late chunking could really help us.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Right.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: You know, get closer to that.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Yeah. It could really bridge that gap between how we communicate.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Yeah.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: And how AI actually processes information.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: That's a good way to put it. Yeah.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: The paper also mentions some future directions.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Yeah.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: They talk about fine tuning. Can you explain what that means?

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Yeah. So the idea is that you could actually fine tune a model specifically for light chunking.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Okay.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: And that might lead to even better results.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Okay.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: So it's like taking a general purpose tool and really sharpening it for a specific task.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: So instead of just using like a pre trained model.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Yeah.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: You would further train it to make it even better at doing this late chunking.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: That's right.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: So you're taking a model that's already good at understanding long text.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Right.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: And then you're saying, hey, get even better at this late chunking stuff.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Exactly.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: That's a very promising area.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: It is.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: For future research.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Yeah. And it opens up even more questions. That's right. Like, could there be even more sophisticated approaches.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Yeah.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: To chunking that build on this core idea? That's a question of, you know, preserving context.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Yeah.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Could we combine this with other cutting edge techniques to really enhance AI's understanding of language?

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Yeah. It feels like we're on the edge of this new era in AI. It's exciting where these language models are becoming so sophisticated.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: I know. It's a really cool time to be working in this field.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: I feel like this deep dive has been so eye opening. I feel like I have a much better understanding.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: I'm glad to hear that.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Of how late chunking works.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Yeah.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: And why it's such a big deal.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: It's always fun to talk about these things.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: It is.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Yeah. It really is a fascinating time.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: So before we wrap up.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Yeah.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Is there anything else from the paper that you think our listeners should know?

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: One thing that I thought was really cool was that they actually made their code publicly available.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Oh, wow.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Which is great. You know, for transparency and reproducibility.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: So important.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: It really helps accelerate that progress.

subtitles.speaker: A
subtitles.text: Absolutely. So if you had to pick just one key takeaway, what would you want our listener to remember about late chunking?

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: I think the biggest takeaway is that this is like a paradigm shift in how we think about these text embeddings. It's not just about chopping up the text. It's about understanding and preserving the meaning within those pieces.

subtitles.speaker: B
subtitles.text: Exactly.
